slides.title: Introduction to Cancellations, Reinstatements and Rewrites
slides.notes: Introduction to the lesson topics.
slides.narration: Welcome to our exploration of cancellations, reinstatements, and rewrites within Guidewire PolicyCenter. These processes are crucial for managing the lifecycle of an insurance policy and ensuring compliance with business rules. We'll dive into how cancellations occur, the intricacies of reinstatements, and when a policy rewrite is necessary. By the end of this lesson, you'll have a solid grasp of how these processes interact with the PolicyCenter data model and how you can customize them to fit your organization's needs.
slides.ocrText: Cancellation, Reinstatement, and Rewrite

slides.title: Understanding Cancellations
slides.notes: Discuss the ease of policy cancellation by insured versus insurer.
slides.narration: Cancellations are an essential part of policy management. An insured can cancel a policy at their discretion, often due to finding better rates elsewhere. However, when an insurer initiates a cancellation, it must be justified—typically for reasons like non-payment or fraudulent activity. From a developer's perspective, understanding the triggers and rules for cancellations in the data model is key to implementing effective business logic.
slides.ocrText:
Lesson
objectives

* Describe how to cancel a policy

Explain the consequences of cancelling a
policy

Describe policy reinstatement

Describe policy rewrites

slides.title: Cancellation Process
slides.notes: Deep dive into the cancellation process.
slides.narration: The cancellation process in PolicyCenter involves several steps and checks. It begins when a cancellation job is initiated, either manually or automatically. As developers, we need to ensure that the system correctly identifies eligible policies and applies the appropriate cancellation reasons and refund methods. This involves configuring the policy data model to reflect these business rules accurately.
slides.ocrText:
Gi

Darren
Insurance
Product Manager

Our business has a lot of customized processes for
cancellation. How does the cancellation process work in
PolicyCenter?

slides.title: Cancellation Scenarios
slides.notes: Explore common business cases for cancellations.
slides.narration: Common scenarios for cancellations include non-payment of premiums or discovering a better deal. For each scenario, the system must handle different workflows and refund methods. In our configurations, we must ensure that the policy data model is flexible enough to accommodate these variations, such as pro-rata or short-rate refunds, depending on the cancellation reason.
slides.ocrText:
| Cancellation transactions
Cancellations, reinstatements, and
rewrites are related

« You can only reinstate a cancelled policy
¢ You must cancel a policy to rewrite it

slides.title: Business Cases for Cancellations
slides.originalNotes:
Cancellations
It is easier for the insured to cancel a policy than for an insurer to cancel a policy. The insured can choose to discontinue a policy without reason. However,  an insurer cannot discontinue a policy unless the insurer can demonstrate just cause, such as non-payment of premiums,  purposefully providing inaccurate information at the time of submission or fraud.

Common business cases:
Insured finds a better price elsewhere.
Insured has not paid premium; insurer cancels the policy.
slides.notes:
Cancellations
It is easier for the insured to cancel a policy than for an insurer to cancel a policy. The insured can choose to discontinue a policy without reason. However,  an insurer cannot discontinue a policy unless the insurer can demonstrate just cause, such as non-payment of premiums,  purposefully providing inaccurate information at the time of submission or fraud.

Common business cases:
Insured finds a better price elsewhere.
Insured has not paid premium; insurer cancels the policy.
slides.narration: Cancellations often reflect a dynamic insurance landscape where policyholders seek better terms, or insurers enforce policy terms. For developers, understanding these business cases helps in crafting a system that can easily track and process cancellations. It’s crucial to design workflows that capture the necessary data points, such as cancellation reasons and effective dates, to automate and streamline these processes.
slides.ocrText:
| Cancellations

Cancellation

slides.title: Initiating a Cancellation
slides.notes: Introduction to starting a cancellation job.
slides.narration: Initiating a cancellation job involves selecting the appropriate menu action and setting parameters like source, reason, and refund method. The process needs to be intuitive for users but robust enough to handle complex business rules. As developers, our job is to ensure that the user interface correctly reflects these options and that underlying entity changes are captured and processed efficiently in the data model.

slides.title: Cancellation Workflow
slides.notes: Outline of the cancellation workflow steps.
slides.narration: A typical cancellation workflow consists of initiating the job, inputting key details like effective date, and selecting the desired refund method. It's a critical path that needs seamless integration with the billing system to ensure the correct financial transactions are initiated. Developers should focus on ensuring that the UI and backend processes are synchronized to prevent errors in policy status or financial records.

slides.title: Demonstration: Canceling a Policy
slides.originalNotes:
Demonstration
DEMO
The "Cancel Policy" menu action is available only for policies that do not already have completed cancellation jobs. Cancellation jobs are not always initiated manually.  They could be initiated automatically by a billing system- To start a cancellation job, provide 1) the cancellation source (insured or insurer), 2) The cancellation reason (drop- down), 3) The refund method (describe), 4) The effectivedate for the cancellation.
1.Locate a policy you created to cancel.
2.Actions -> Cancel Policy Enter source and select a reason. Describe each
3.Tell learners that the reason you select will determine the Refund Method, and show it change with different reasons (e.g., Criminal Conduct vs. Policy not- taken). The refund methods are outlined  the student workbook for review. "Flat" : refund all money - typically used if the policy has not yet become effective, "pro rata": prorate ,or "short rate": prorate the refund and subtract processing fee.
After you enter the required information, select Start Cancellation- This is step 2 in a two-step wizard process-You can either Schedule Cancellation or Cancel Now. The "Schedule Cancellation“ option will schedule the job to be completed on the cancellation effective date- The "Cancel Now" option completes the job immediately, but the policy is still in force until the Cancellation Effective date.

slides.narration: In this demonstration, we'll walk through canceling a policy in PolicyCenter. Start by locating a policy you wish to cancel, and navigate to the 'Actions' menu to select 'Cancel Policy'. Note how the choice of cancellation reason impacts the refund method, which the system dynamically adjusts based on your selection. Observe how the wizard guides you through scheduling or executing the cancellation, ensuring the policy status updates accurately within the system.

reinstatement work?

slides.title: Understanding Reinstatements
slides.originalNotes:
Reinstatement
Common business case:
If the insured misses a premium payment, a cancellation may occur. After the insured makes a payment, the reinstatement occurs.
slides.notes:
Reinstatement
Common business case:
If the insured misses a premium payment, a cancellation may occur. After the insured makes a payment, the reinstatement occurs.
slides.narration: Reinstatements are essential when a policyholder misses a payment but then rectifies it. They allow the policy to resume without needing to create a new one. For developers, it's important to configure the system to handle reinstatements smoothly, ensuring that the policy's status and billing records are updated correctly and that any gaps in coverage are documented as per business requirements.
slides.ocrText:
| Reinstatement

Cancellation Reinstatement

Pac

Policy term !

¢ Reinstates cancelled policy with original terms

* Cancellation and reinstatement always have the same effective date
* No lapse in coverage

¢ Reinstatements are configurable

slides.title: Reinstatement Process
slides.notes: Overview of the reinstatement process.
slides.narration: The reinstatement process involves verifying payment receipt and updating the policy status from canceled to active. This requires coordination between the billing system and PolicyCenter to ensure accuracy. Developers should focus on creating seamless integrations that trigger reinstatements automatically upon payment confirmation, reducing manual intervention and potential errors.
slides.ocrText:

slides.title: Reinstatement Scenarios
slides.notes: Explore common scenarios for reinstatements.
slides.narration: Scenarios for reinstatements often involve late premium payments or temporary lapses in coverage. Each scenario may require different handling in terms of policy effective dates and coverage terms. As developers, our goal is to build flexibility into the system, allowing for these variations while maintaining compliance with underwriting guidelines.

slides.title: Challenges in Reinstatements
slides.notes: Discuss challenges developers might face.
slides.narration: One of the challenges in reinstatements is ensuring data consistency across systems. The policy status, billing records, and any associated endorsements must align to reflect the reinstatement accurately. Developers need to implement robust data validation and synchronization processes to mitigate risks of mismatch or data corruption during reinstatement transactions.

Cancellations and reinstatements are clear, but what
about rewrites?

slides.title: Understanding Rewrites
slides.originalNotes:
Rewrites
A rewrite involves a change to a policy that is significant enough that it cannot be captured with a policy change. When a mid-term rewrite is performed, it generally is for the remainder of the term or for a new full term. With a full- term rewrite, the policy is flat canceled. In most cases, the rewrite effective date is the same as the cancellation effective date. This is typically done when:

The original policy was issued with a significant error, and the policy needs to be reissued to remedy the error .

In some cases, the rewrite effective date is after the cancellation effective dates. This is typically performed when:

The original policy was in force and then cancelled. It now needs to be reinstated, but the reinstatement must be effective some time after the cancellation indicating a gap in coverage. This type of scenario cannot be conducted with a reinstatement transaction because a reinstatement transaction must have the same effective and cancellation date.
The original policy was in force under producer A and is now being transferred to producer B. A policy’s producer is inherent to a policy and cannot be changed through a change transaction.
slides.notes:
Rewrites
A rewrite involves a change to a policy that is significant enough that it cannot be captured with a policy change. When a mid-term rewrite is performed, it generally is for the remainder of the term or for a new full term. With a full- term rewrite, the policy is flat canceled. In most cases, the rewrite effective date is the same as the cancellation effective date. This is typically done when:

The original policy was issued with a significant error, and the policy needs to be reissued to remedy the error .

In some cases, the rewrite effective date is after the cancellation effective dates. This is typically performed when:

The original policy was in force and then cancelled. It now needs to be reinstated, but the reinstatement must be effective some time after the cancellation indicating a gap in coverage. This type of scenario cannot be conducted with a reinstatement transaction because a reinstatement transaction must have the same effective and cancellation date.
The original policy was in force under producer A and is now being transferred to producer B. A policy’s producer is inherent to a policy and cannot be changed through a change transaction.
slides.narration: Rewrites are necessary when significant changes occur that cannot be effectively managed with a simple policy change, such as correcting errors or changing producers. They involve canceling the existing policy and issuing a new one. Understanding the conditions that necessitate a rewrite helps developers implement workflows that capture these changes efficiently, ensuring that the new policy reflects the correct coverage and terms.

slides.title: Full-term Rewrites
slides.originalNotes:
Full-term rewrite
Cancellations must be effective on the start date of the original policy term in a situation when the policy is flat canceled. In the case of a flat cancel followed by a full-term rewrite, the rewrite can start on a different effective date than the cancellation date. A full term rewrite results in the original policy term being completely wiped out. A mid-term rewrite behaves differently.

The Application Guide's *Rewrite Key Features" section discusses the differences between the two in detail.
slides.notes:
Full-term rewrite
Cancellations must be effective on the start date of the original policy term in a situation when the policy is flat canceled. In the case of a flat cancel followed by a full-term rewrite, the rewrite can start on a different effective date than the cancellation date. A full term rewrite results in the original policy term being completely wiped out. A mid-term rewrite behaves differently.

The Application Guide's *Rewrite Key Features" section discusses the differences between the two in detail.
slides.narration: Full-term rewrites typically occur when a policy is flat canceled due to significant issues. The new policy term can start on a different date, providing a clean slate. Developers should ensure that the system can handle these transitions smoothly, updating all related entities like billing and claims to reflect the newly issued policy accurately.
slides.ocrText:
| Full-term rewrite

Cancellation Rewrite

slides.title: Mid-term Rewrites
slides.originalNotes:
Mid-term rewrites
When performing a midterm rewrite, you would first cancel with the reason •policy rewritten (midterm)". Only if there is a completed cancellation with an effective date not equal to start date of the policy, you can do a midterm rewrite.
slides.notes:
Mid-term rewrites
When performing a midterm rewrite, you would first cancel with the reason •policy rewritten (midterm)". Only if there is a completed cancellation with an effective date not equal to start date of the policy, you can do a midterm rewrite.
slides.narration: Mid-term rewrites are performed when policy changes occur mid-way through the term but are substantial enough to require a new policy issuance. This process involves canceling the existing policy mid-term and starting a new term. For developers, it’s crucial to implement logic that identifies eligible policies and facilitates a smooth transition without disrupting coverage or billing cycles.

slides.title: Rewrites: Key Differences
slides.notes: Outline differences between full-term and mid-term rewrites.
slides.narration: Understanding the differences between full-term and mid-term rewrites is essential for accurate policy management. While full-term rewrites reset the policy entirely, mid-term rewrites adjust the policy from a specific point in time. As developers, our task is to ensure that these processes are clearly delineated in the system, with appropriate checks and balances to guide users through each scenario.

slides.title: Common Rewrite Scenarios
slides.notes: Explore scenarios requiring rewrites.
slides.narration: Scenarios requiring rewrites often involve significant errors in the original policy or changes in underwriting guidelines. These scenarios are critical for maintaining accurate coverage and compliance. Developers should focus on building flexible workflows that allow users to initiate rewrites efficiently while ensuring data integrity across all related policy entities.

slides.title: Data Model Considerations
slides.notes: Impact of cancellations, reinstatements, and rewrites on the data model.
slides.narration: Cancellations, reinstatements, and rewrites all have significant impacts on the PolicyCenter data model. Each transaction type affects policy and billing entities differently, and ensuring data consistency is paramount. Developers should pay close attention to how these processes interact with the broader data architecture, implementing robust validation and synchronization mechanisms to maintain system integrity.

slides.title: Integrating with Billing Systems
slides.notes: Discuss integration points with billing systems.
slides.narration: Integration with billing systems is crucial for handling financial transactions associated with cancellations, reinstatements, and rewrites. These integrations ensure that billing records accurately reflect policy changes, minimizing discrepancies and reducing manual reconciliation efforts. Developers should focus on leveraging Guidewire's integration frameworks to create seamless data flows between PolicyCenter and billing systems.

slides.title: Customizing Workflows
slides.notes: Discuss customization opportunities for workflows.
slides.narration: Customization of cancellation, reinstatement, and rewrite workflows allows organizations to tailor processes to their specific business needs. This involves configuring PCF files, defining new business rules in Gosu, and customizing UI elements to capture necessary data inputs efficiently. As developers, our role is to ensure these customizations enhance user experience while maintaining compliance with regulatory requirements.

slides.title: UI Considerations
slides.notes: Impact of UI design on transaction processes.
slides.narration: The design of the user interface plays a critical role in how effectively users can initiate and manage cancellations, reinstatements, and rewrites. UI elements must be intuitive, guiding users through complex processes with clear prompts and validation messages. Developers should focus on creating user-friendly interfaces that minimize errors and enhance productivity, leveraging Guidewire’s design patterns for consistency.

slides.title: Best Practices
slides.notes: Share best practices for implementing these processes.
slides.narration: Implementing cancellations, reinstatements, and rewrites effectively requires adhering to best practices. This includes thorough testing of workflows, ensuring accurate data transition across entities, and maintaining clear documentation of process logic. Developers should also focus on continuous improvement, regularly reviewing system performance and user feedback to refine these processes over time.

slides.title: Common Pitfalls
slides.notes: Discuss common pitfalls and how to avoid them.
slides.narration: Avoiding common pitfalls in managing cancellations, reinstatements, and rewrites is crucial for maintaining system reliability. Pitfalls often include data mismatches, incomplete integrations, and user errors due to complex workflows. Developers should implement comprehensive validation checks and provide clear user guidance to mitigate these risks, ensuring that the system operates smoothly under various scenarios.

slides.title: Conclusion and Next Steps
slides.notes: Summarize key takeaways and preview next lesson.
slides.narration: In this lesson, we covered the intricacies of cancellations, reinstatements, and rewrites, exploring their impact on the PolicyCenter data model and workflows. Understanding these processes is crucial for effective policy management. As we move into the next lesson on out-of-sequence transactions, you'll see how these foundational concepts play a role in handling more complex scenarios. Keep these insights in mind as we continue to build on your expertise in PolicyCenter.
